lead_paragraph: Four venerable old-economy industrial warhorses, Bethlehem Steel, W. R. Grace, Crown Cork and Seal and Owens-Illinois, were designated for deletion from the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks yesterday. They are to be replaced by two prominent technology companies, Intuit and Symbol Technologies, plus a utility company, Allegheny Energy, and a financial services company, the Ambac Financial Group.

lead_paragraph: A chart on the DataBank page on Nov. 12, 19 and 26 and last Sunday showing the weekly high, low and closing levels of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index carried an erroneous scale, overstating the figures. A corrected chart, with a new scale, appears today, on Page 21.

main_headline: Around the Island
snippet: Symbol Technologies Inc will become one of companies that make up Standard & Poor's 500-stock index (S)
lead_paragraph: Symbol Technologies Inc. (NYSE: SBL) will become one of the companies that make up Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, starting tomorrow. Symbol, which has its headquarters in Holtsville, pioneered bar-code scanning and wireless technology. . . . The Kimco Realty Corporation (NYSE: KIM) of New Hyde Park, the country's largest owner and operator of neighborhood shopping centers, increased its quarterly dividend by 4 cents on Monday, to 72 cents a share. This was the second dividend increase in the last six months. The previous increase, in July, was 2 cents, from 66 cents to 68 cents a share. . . . The Long Island Works Coalition will sponsor the first Internship Connection Fair for local college and high school students. The event, co-sponsored by the Long Island Association, will take place Jan. 9 at EAB Plaza in Uniondale. . . . The Northrop Grumman Corporation has appointed Philip Teel to head its Long Island operations, which engineer and manufacture airborne early-warning and electronic warfare systems. Mr. Teel, whose title will be sector vice president, has worked in the aerospace industry for two decades. He was most recently a vice president of the Raytheon Corporation. He succeeds Paul Coco, who retired for health reasons only two weeks ago and who died last week. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

main_headline: Wall Street Bids Farewell to a Bad Year

But a final sag in the Nasdaq composite index on Friday made it certain that the technology-laden index would finish the year with the worst annual performance in its 29-year history. A 39 percent slide followed a record 86 percent Nasdaq leap in 1999.

main_headline: The Dividend Check Isn't in the Mail

lead_paragraph: FOR the past 20 years, the dividends that corporate America doles out to its shareholders have won little respect. lead_paragraph: DAIMLERCHRYSLER is not a marriage in which American mutual fund managers have had much faith. main_headline: Corrections
snippet: Correction of Business Day chart August 6 on steepest declines for main stock gauges; Standard & Poor's performance explained
lead_paragraph: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing the steepest declines for the main stock gauges during bear markets misstated the most recent performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. It reached its low on July 23, not this Monday. And the low followed the most recent peak by 821 calendar days, not 834. At its low, the index was 47.8 percent below its peak, not 45.4 percent, making the decline the sixth worst among the major indexes, not the seventh.

main_headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Shares Drop After Removal From Index
snippet: Shares of Palm Inc fall as much as 18 percent after Standard & Poor's say Palm will be dropped from its 500-stock index (S)
lead_paragraph: Shares of Palm Inc. fell as much as 18 percent yesterday after Standard & Poor's said Palm, the hand-held computer maker, would be dropped from its index. Palm shares dropped 16 cents, or 16.3 percent, to 82 cents and traded as low as 78 cents. Shares of companies removed from the S.&. P. 500 often fall, and those added often rise, as managers of about $800 billion in funds seek to match the index's performance by adjusting their holdings. Palm's market capitalization has fallen by more than $52 billion, to $568 million. The value was once greater than Ford Motor's. Palm was replaced in the S.& P. 500 yesterday by the Monsanto Company, an agricultural chemicals maker being spun off by Pharmacia. Shares of Pharmacia rose $2.05, to $46.25. Palm's sales fell 38 percent last year, to $1.03 billion from $1.6 billion. The shares reached $165 on March 2, 2000, their first day of public trading.

main_headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec Will Be Added To S.& P. 500
snippet: Symantec Corp will be added to Standard & Poor's 500 index after close of trading March 28; will replace Household International, which is being acquired by HSBC Holdings (S)
lead_paragraph: The Symantec Corporation, the world's largest maker of software for protecting against computer viruses, will be added to Standard & Poor's index of the 500 biggest United States companies after the close of trading on Friday. The software maker will replace Household International Inc., the financial services company that is being acquired by HSBC Holdings, Standard & Poor's said yesterday in a statement on its Internet site. Symantec shares fell $3.47, to $39.09. Shares of companies that are added to the S.& P. 500 index usually rise because managers of the approximately $1 trillion of investments that are tied to the index need to buy them for their portfolios. Standard & Poor's will also make changes to the S.& P. MidCap 400 Index and the S.& P. SmallCap 600 Index. Fair, Isaac & Company will replace Symantec in the MidCap 400 Index, while Flowers Foods Inc. will be added to the SmallCap 600.

main_headline: Is the Big Board Getting Creaky?
snippet: Gretchen Morgenson column on Governance Metrics International study that found stocks of companies at top of its ranking for good corporate governance outperformed Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in meaningful way; those ranked lowest significan...
lead_paragraph: JUST a few months ago, Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, was a Wall Street hero. He brokered the peace between securities regulators and big brokerage firms, leading to a settlement in the Wall Street research investigation. He also moved forcefully to improve corporate governance standards among companies whose shares are traded on the Big Board. Quietly, Mr. Grasso became something of a statesman.

main_headline: WAL-MART TO BUY BACK $10 BILLION IN STOCK
snippet: Wal-Mart Stores, responding to changes in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index weighting that are expected to cause its stock to decline, says it will buy back up to $10 billion of its shares (S)
lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that it would repurchase as much as $10 billion in stock, the company's biggest proposed buyback in at least a decade. The repurchases would be made as more shares of the company trade because of weighting changes in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Wal-Mart's representation was expected to decline after a change in the benchmark index's methodology. Changes in the index could lead to the sale of about $8.4 billion in Wal-Mart shares, a Smith Barney analyst, Deborah Weinswig, wrote in a report. Wal-Mart is based in Bentonville, Ark.

main_headline: Last Year's Worries Wane
snippet: Wall Street analysts say stock market performed relatively well in 2004, despite investor worries, buoyed by stronger-than-expected corporate profits and interest rates that were lower than feared; Dow Jones industrial average gained meager 3.15 p...
lead_paragraph: INVESTORS spent much of 2004 fretting over rising interest rates, surging oil prices and the presidential election. But those worries turned out to be excessive, Wall Street analysts say. The market performed relatively well, buoyed by corporate profits that were stronger than expected and interest rates that were lower than feared, they say.

lead_paragraph: From department stores to discount chains, sales were dismal last month, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on American consumers.

main_headline: S.& P. Index Climbs Past the Record It Set 7 Years Ago
snippet: The most widely followed benchmark of American stocks surpassed a previous high set amid the Internet boom.
lead_paragraph: The stock market yesterday clawed back to where it was seven years ago during the heady days of technology and the Internet boom — and it had to overcome an overnight sell-off in China to get there.

snippet: Current conditions certainly look different from those of March 2000. But several subsurface issues suggest that we shouldn’t be too sanguine.
lead_paragraph: THE Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is close to where it stood just before the bursting of the Internet bubble in March 2000. That makes some investors nervous: Could the market be forming another bubble?

main_headline: With Bailout Picture Unclear, Markets Tumble
snippet: The Dow Jones industrials closed down 372 points, or 3.3 percent, at 11,015.69 after spending the day deep in negative territory.
lead_paragraph: Fresh concerns about the biggest government bailout in history sent stock markets down sharply on Monday, while a weakening dollar sparked a frantic rush into commodities as investors remained nervous about the health of Wall Street.

main_headline: Strongest Election Day Stock Rally in 24 Years
snippet: Wall Street had its largest Election Day rally in 24 years as millions of American voters went to the polls.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street built on recent gains Tuesday as reduced volatility and easing in the credit markets helped give stocks their strongest Election Day rally in 24 years.

main_headline: Markets Move Lower in Late Trading
snippet: Wall Street started another decline in the last hour of trading after clawing back from early losses as buyers struggled with troubling news from disparate corners of the financial world.
lead_paragraph: Once again, Wall Street held on until 3 p.m., then lost its grip.

snippet: The Standard & Poor’s 500 is down almost as far as it was in the worst year it ever experienced, at the height of the Great Depression.
lead_paragraph: THIS is shaping up as the year when almost nothing went up.

main_headline: Stocks Rally to Start Year; Will January Be an Omen?
snippet: In 60 of the last 80 years, the performance of the S.& P. 500 in January has accurately predicted whether stocks would end higher or lower for the full year, one analyst said.
lead_paragraph: Among Wall Street’s many proverbs, traders say one stands above the others: “As goes January, so goes the year.”

main_headline: Do New Year Stocks Foreshadow Year-End Stocks?
snippet: A historical look at whether the behavior of the market at each year’s start holds meaning as an indicator of things to come.
lead_paragraph: The stock market marked the New Year with one of its best performances ever. Then it put on one of its worst performances ever.

main_headline: 2009’s First Month Disappoints Investors
snippet: The stock market fell for a fourth consecutive week on poor earnings reports and on data showing that the economy contracted in the fourth quarter at the fastest pace in a quarter-century.

main_headline: A 10-Year Stretch That’s Worse Than It Looks
snippet: The Standard & Poor’s 500 just ended its worst decade ever.
lead_paragraph: IN the last 82 years — the history of the Standard & Poor’s 500 — the stock market has been through one Great Depression and numerous recessions. It has experienced bubbles and busts, bull markets and bear markets.

main_headline: For One Day at Least, Wall Street Turns Higher
snippet: After the Fed chairman tamped down fears about nationalizing banks, investors nearly erased Monday’s losses.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street bounced back on Tuesday from its lowest levels in nearly 12 years after the chairman of the Federal Reserve tamped down investor fears that the government would nationalize major banks.

main_headline: Technology and Telecom Shares Send Markets Lower
snippet: In a shift, the financial sector was the only corner of the market in positive territory in late trading, as shares of companies like Google, I.B.M., Verizon and AT&T all declined.
lead_paragraph: A slump in technology and telecommunications companies pulled Wall Street lower on Monday, as two major market indexes carved new bear-market lows.

main_headline: Markets Climb on Upbeat Housing Report
snippet: With investors cheered by a surprising increase in home-building last month, major market indexes rose on Tuesday to their highest levels since late February.
lead_paragraph: Unemployment may still be rising and the economy may be nowhere near a bottom, but optimism reigned on Wall Street Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: AFTER witnessing several promising rallies dissolve since stocks slid into a bear market in October 2007, investors may indeed be skeptical about the latest surge in share prices.

snippet: As stocks climbed on Monday, a leading stock index crossed a milestone that seemed unthinkable during the worst declines of the bear market: It turned positive for the year.
lead_paragraph: For many investors, breaking even never felt so good.

main_headline: Solid Earnings, but Soft Revenue
snippet: While overall profits were down by about a third from a year earlier, more than three-quarters of the companies beat analysts’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: If the key to happiness is low expectations, then stock investors must be over the moon. More than a third of the companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index have reported second-quarter earnings. While overall profits were down by about a third from a year earlier, more than three-quarters of the companies beat analysts’ expectations, according to Thomson Reuters. That is on track to be the highest ratio ever.

main_headline: This Time, the Blue Chips Are Rallying, Too
snippet: Since early May, shares of large, industry-leading companies with strong balance sheets have joined the parade, along with more speculative bets.
lead_paragraph: THE stock market rally that began in March, only to stall in May, appears to be back on track.

snippet: Large-growth shares are suddenly attractive again, but investors should keep history in mind before making a commitment.

main_headline: Some Analysts See an End to Market Rally
snippet: Art Cashin, the director of floor operations at UBS, said, “The people who know are getting out early.” The ratio of insider selling to insider buying soared to 30 to 1 in August.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a blockbuster summer for the bulls on Wall Street. Shares are up more than 15 percent since mid-July, investors are feeling optimistic, and once-idle money is pouring back into equities.

lead_paragraph: The United States stock market has just completed its best six months since 1933. From March 9 to Sept. 9, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index leaped by 53 percent.

main_headline: Great Year, but S.&P. Closes in on its Worst Decade Ever
snippet: The smart money in the millennium’s first decade — or at least its final year — was in junk bonds, and the junkier the better.
lead_paragraph: THE decade now ending could be called the Zeroes, but for the fact that stock investors only wish they had done so well.

main_headline: What the Bottom Line Hides
snippet: Recent quarterly results showing high profit are often based on cost cutting, which may not be sustainable. Revenue is a more telling indicator.
lead_paragraph: INVESTORS are always told to focus on a company’s profit, or bottom line. And sure enough, a big reason for the recent stock market surge is a spate of better-than-expected earnings reports.

main_headline: Bonds Boom as Investors Flock Back
snippet: Some analysts call the resurgence a sign that credit markets have recovered. Others warn that bond prices could roll backward if the economy stumbles.
lead_paragraph: The swift rally in stock markets this year caught everyone’s attention. But with far less fanfare, a frenzy has been taking place in the market for corporate bonds.

snippet: At this point, traditional growth sectors like materials and consumer discretionary stocks may not be the bargains you would expect.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the economy appears on the verge of rebounding  as it does today  investors tend to gravitate toward economically sensitive stocks, which stand to benefit from improving financial conditions.

main_headline: Time Heals Everything in Quarterly Statements
snippet: For many investors, the 12-month performance of brokerage accounts and 401(k)’s should soon look much better. How will that affect their market outlook?
lead_paragraph: THOUGH stocks have soared more than 50 percent since the market hit bottom in March, the sentiment of individual investors is hardly euphoric.

main_headline: A New Chinese Stock Exchange Opens With a Surge
snippet: Investors went on a buying spree the first day of trading Friday of the Growth Enterprise Market, sending the shares of some companies soaring as much as 210 percent.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  The highly anticipated opening of China’s new Nasdaq-style stock exchange last Friday is already being seen as a watershed moment for the country’s capital markets, providing new opportunities for Chinese investors and an alternative source of financing for upstart companies.

main_headline: A Rally That Needs More ‘E’
snippet: Earnings need to rise — and soon — to continue a rally that has lifted stock prices by more than 60 percent since early March, Paul J. Lim says.
lead_paragraph: IN the first leg of a bull market, when optimism and euphoria are ascendant, investors are willing to bet that the economy will improve and that corporate profit growth is just around the corner. This faith manifests itself not just in rising share prices, but also in rising price-to-earnings ratios.

main_headline: Get Ready for Half a Recovery
snippet: Until the debt clouds disappear in the economy, small business can’t lead a rebound.
lead_paragraph: A ROBUST economic recovery in 2010 is certainly on most investors’ wish lists as this year draws to a close. A return to prosperity would not only mean an end to our long financial nightmare, but it would also buttress a rebounding stock market, one of 2009’s few bright spots.

main_headline: Hedge Fund Assets Go Back Above $2 Trillion
snippet: Hedge fund assets exceeded the $2 trillion mark for the first time in a year as cash pulled from the financial markets in 2008 found its way back to alternative investments.
lead_paragraph: Hedge fund assets exceeded the $2 trillion mark for the first time in a year as cash pulled from the financial markets in 2008 found its way back to alternative investments. Strong returns from hedge funds this year could help ease investors’ concerns about the huge losses the industry experienced last year, helping to spur a further increase in investor cash.

main_headline: Now Entering Phase 2 of the Market’s Comeback
snippet: Financial stocks have advanced more than 130 percent since the market’s March 9 lows, but have fallen 4 percent since the fourth quarter began.
lead_paragraph: THE bull market that came to life in March may already be morphing into a new incarnation: a more mature rally that’s less euphoric, broad-based or, for that matter, certain.

main_headline: Dow Slips for Third Day, but Dollar Strengthens
snippet: Wall Street investors sold off on Thursday as light trading amplified concerns about foreign debt and a weaker-than-expected report on the U.S. labor market.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street investors sold off on Thursday as light trading amplified concerns about foreign debt and a weaker-than-expected report on the labor market.

main_headline:
Merger Lessons
In the Oil Patch
snippet: The oil company is acquiring XTO Energy for a price that is more than 30 percent below its June 2008 high.
lead_paragraph: When ConocoPhillips bet big on gas with the $36 billion purchase of Burlington Resources in 2005, it was widely expected to cause copycat deals. Instead the deal became a cautionary tale in the oil patch. Investors are clearly concerned about a repeat performance. They’ve wiped almost $20 billion off Exxon Mobil’s market capitalization since the oil giant agreed to buy XTO Energy for $31 billion this week. But they should give Exxon more credit for learning from its rival’s blunders.

main_headline: A Crystal Ball, With Caveats and Corrections
snippet: Stock market professionals see a range of possibilities for 2010 — and few are completely upbeat.
lead_paragraph: IT has been a wonderful stretch for the stock market, especially if you disregard last winter’s steep plunge, to say nothing of the dismal year that preceded it.

main_headline: Patience, Please, With That Investment Plan
snippet: Were you out of the stock market when it turned around in March? You’ve got plenty of company.
lead_paragraph: THE stock market sometimes moves astonishingly fast, yet much patience is required to take advantage of those swift moves. Both of those valuable, seemingly incongruous lessons have emerged from the market’s performance over the last year.

main_headline: A Way to Share in a Nation’s Growth
snippet: A new type of security called a trill, representing one-trillionth of a country’s gross domestic product, could be a major new source of government funding.
lead_paragraph: CORPORATIONS raise money by issuing both debt and equity, the latter giving investors an implicit share in future profits. Governments should do something like this, too, and not just rely on debt.

main_headline: For Savers, It Was Hardly a Lost Decade
snippet: With diversification and regular contributions, many investors could have doubled their account balances in the last decade.
lead_paragraph: It was the age of zeroes, the epoch of naughts, an era when we started with something and added just about nothing.

main_headline: Oops, There Go the Tail Winds
snippet: If the market is a predictor of trends, investors are now handicapping the performance of the economy in the spring and summer — and are seeing some bumps ahead.
lead_paragraph: IN hindsight, it makes perfect sense that equities started to surge last March.

main_headline: Why All Earnings Are Not Equal
snippet: When the market is roaring and the economy isn’t, smart investors should scrutinize how company profits are figured to make sure results justify higher valuations.
lead_paragraph: AFTER a rip-roaring performance in 2009, the stock market has continued its upward climb. A reason to celebrate? Sure. But also a good time to check whether a company in which you have a stake keeps its books in a way that reflects reality.

main_headline: As Dividends Have Fallen, So May They Rise
snippet: For the first time in at least half a century, American companies announced more dividend cuts than increases in 2009.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in at least half a century, American companies announced more dividend cuts than increases in 2009, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris reports.

main_headline: Comeback of the Year? Try Corporate Profits
snippet: Earnings growth has been a pleasant surprise for stock investors. Whether it’s sustainable for the rest of the year is another question.
lead_paragraph: THE market remains worried about plenty of things — including a sharp decline late last week, and the spreading debt crisis in Europe. But, recently, it has appeared that investors are ready to strike one item off their list of concerns: corporate profits.

main_headline: Gensler Lays Out Timeline for Wild Wall St. Trading

main_headline: Exchanges Agree in Principle on New Trading Rules

main_headline: Hedge Funds Post Gains but Still Lag S.& P.

lead_paragraph: Hedge funds posted modest gains in April, drawing in more capital from investors. The index, made up of dozens of funds across different strategies, is up 4.35 percent for the year.

main_headline: Waddell Named as Mystery Trader in Market Plunge
snippet: A big mystery seller of futures contracts during the market meltdown last week was not a hedge fund or a high-frequency trader as many have suspected, but the money manager Waddell & Reed Financial, according to a document obtained by Reuters.
lead_paragraph: 6:58 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Nelson D. Schwartz provides more details about Waddell & Reed’s role in the market plunge.

main_headline: Waddell Defends Its Trades During Flash Crash
snippet: Waddell & Reed Financial, a Kansas-based mutual fund company, said an internal analysis of trading activity indicated it was not the cause of the flash crash that briefly wiped out $1 trillion in stock market wealth earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: Waddell & Reed Financial, a Kansas-based mutual fund company, said an internal analysis of trading activity indicated it was not the cause of the flash crash that briefly wiped out $1 trillion in stock market wealth earlier this month, Reuters reports.

main_headline: S.E.C. Enforcement Unit Examining Flash Crash
snippet: The enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission has begun looking into the sharp stock market drop of May 6, the chairwoman of the agency said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission has begun looking into the sharp stock market drop of May 6, the chairwoman of the agency said on Thursday.

main_headline: S.E.C. Delays Start of Exchange Trading Curbs
snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission delayed trading curbs for Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index listings when they rise or fall 10 percent in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission delayed trading curbs for Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index listings when they rise or fall 10 percent in five minutes, saying they will be implemented within two weeks. The announcement was made in an e-mail statement. NYSE Euronext said earlier Friday that it would not start its trial of the system on June 7 because it had not received S.E.C. authorization. The Nasdaq OMX Group is prepared to introduce circuit breakers on the S.& P. 500 companies it lists on June 14, pending S.E.C. approval, a spokesman, Robert Madden, said.

main_headline: Ways to Protect Your Portfolio From Market Volatility
snippet: For more stability in rough markets, investors might look for strong large-cap companies, as well as those that pay steady dividends.
lead_paragraph: FOR the second time in less than 18 months, the market has taken a steep plunge and the patience of buy-and-hold investors is being put to the test.

main_headline: Cautious Stock Positions May Be Overdone
snippet: Stocks have been a disappointment over the last decade, but some analysts think earnings next year will finally surpass the 2006 peak.
lead_paragraph: The annual investment updates from America’s great university endowments add to evidence that investors have fallen out of love with public equities. After a decade of zero returns, this is understandable. But with stocks cheap and bonds stretched, investors may rue this underweight position.

lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s much-anticipated announcement this month that it was intervening in financial markets was intended to push down interest rates to get the economy moving again.

main_headline: Wall St. Barely Budges Amid Concerns for Europe
snippet: Markets were little changed as talks on an Irish bailout continued and inflation remained low in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Stocks were little changed on Wednesday as concerns about debt problems in Europe persisted, and new reports showed inflation remaining low and the housing sector in the United States remaining weak.

lead_paragraph: Shares on Wall Street declined on Tuesday as heightened uncertainty over conflict in Asia and the debt crisis in Europe sent investors fleeing for safer assets.

main_headline: Stop the Jets
snippet: The stock market has always gone up after the Steelers, Packers or Bears won the Super Bowl. But it fell after the Jets won in 1969. Why would any investor root for the Jets?
lead_paragraph: Much of New York is going crazy over the New York Jets. (If you haven’t followed football, they have scored two playoff upsets and will go to the Super Bowl if they come up with another one in Pittsburgh this Sunday.)

snippet: Two recessions, two bear markets and 12 years after the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index first hit 1,300, it reached that mark again, briefly, this week.
lead_paragraph: The Standard & Poor’s index of 500 stocks first reached 1,300 nearly 12 years ago. This week, it did it again.

main_headline: Markets Retreat as Exxon Leads Energy Shares Down
snippet: Energy producers declined, led by Exxon Mobile, which fell 2.3 percent, its biggest drop since August..
lead_paragraph: Stocks retreated, pulling the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index down from a 32-month high, after a report showed retail sales increased less than forecast, and Exxon Mobil led a decline in energy producers.

main_headline: Anxiety About Oil, Recovery Send Shares Lower
snippet: The Dow closed below 12,000, as oil market jitters and the conflict in Libya served as a reminder of the fragile nature of the global recovery.
lead_paragraph: Worries about oil supply and downbeat economic reports from three continents sent stocks worldwide sharply lower on Thursday, providing a reminder of the fragile nature of the global recovery.

main_headline: After Gaining for 3 Days, Shares Slip on Oil Worries
snippet: Shares slipped amid concerns about fighting in Libya, tension in the Middle East and inflation in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street edged lower Tuesday, reversing three consecutive trading days of advances amid concerns over oil prices and Japan’s nuclear crisis.

main_headline: Hard Knocks and High Hopes
snippet: Despite the earthquake in Japan and political turmoil in North Africa and the Middle East, the average domestic equity fund rose smartly in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: THE first quarter of 2011 was a tempestuous time for the world and for the financial markets. But for the markets, at least, there has seemed to be relatively little lingering damage.

main_headline: Stock Pickers Are No Longer the Stars
snippet: The last decade has shown that many actively managed mutual funds have not exactly zoomed past the overall market in performance.
lead_paragraph: IT’S an old Wall Street pitch: Trust us, we’re experts.

snippet: The rise comes a day after stocks rallied on Wednesday as the Federal Reserve renewed its pledge to stimulate growth with low interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Shares rose, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to the highest level since June 2008, as better-than-estimated corporate earnings tempered investors’ concern over slowing economic growth.

main_headline: Markets Rise Sharply on Retail Sales and Other Economic Data
snippet: Retail sales fell for the first time this year, but stocks rallied by more than 1 percent in part because sales were not as bad as expected.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street surged Tuesday after the United States government released new statistics on the economy, including a retail sales report that traders viewed as positive.

main_headline: Dow Gains 153 Points to End the Quarter Higher
snippet: Developments in Greece helped stocks in the United States, closing a volatile quarter marked by debt concerns in the euro zone and by a struggling economic recovery at home.
lead_paragraph: Stock prices rose sharply on Thursday as easing concerns over European debt troubles and economic growth in the United States helped the Dow Jones industrial average end the second quarter with a modest gain.

main_headline: Relief Rally Vanishes After New Data
snippet: Wall Street followed European and Asian markets higher in relief over the debt agreement in Washington, but the rally was short-lived, as indexes turned negative.
lead_paragraph: Hopes were high for a rally in stocks in the wake of Sunday’s debt limit agreement. But the bounce was a thud.

main_headline: Relief Rally Vanishes After New Data
snippet: Wall Street followed European and Asian markets higher in relief over the debt agreement in Washington, but the rally was short-lived, as indexes turned negative.
lead_paragraph: Hopes were high for a rally in stocks in the wake of Sunday’s debt limit agreement. But the bounce was a thud.

main_headline: For Stocks, Day 7 Since the Walkout
snippet: Stocks have fallen every trading day since Speaker John Boehner walked out of the White House talks on July 22.  The debt deal that eventually emerged has revived recession talk.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday was the seventh trading day since John Boehner walked out of talks with Barack Obama at the White House. That move made it clear that the House speaker would not risk alienating the Tea Party and that if a debt default were to be averted, the president would have to capitulate on virtually all issues or defy Congress by claiming the debt limit legislation was unconstitutional. He chose to capitulate.

main_headline: Stocks Are Still Expensive
snippet: Relative to earnings, stocks still look costly.
lead_paragraph: The main problem for the stock market is obviously the economy. But it’s not the only problem. Stocks are also under pressure because they are fairly expensive right now relative to earnings.

main_headline: Stocks Plunge on Fears of Global Turmoil
snippet: American indexes fell around 5 percent as new data heightened fears that the United States may be headed toward a double-dip recession and that Europe’s debt crisis could widen.
lead_paragraph: What began as a weak day in the stock markets ended in the worst rout in more than two years, as investors dumped stocks amid anxiety that both Europe and the United States were failing to fix deepening economic problems.

main_headline: Multiple Fears Weigh on Markets
snippet: Aug. 5, 2011 - Concerns about Europe's sovereign debt crisis and fears of a double-dip recession in the U.S. are weighing heavily on markets.
lead_paragraph: Aug. 5, 2011 - Concerns about Europe's sovereign debt crisis and fears of a double-dip recession in the U.S. are weighing heavily on markets.

lead_paragraph: Aug. 5, 2011 - Concerns about Europe's sovereign debt crisis and fears of a double-dip recession in the U.S. are weighing heavily on markets.

main_headline: As Dizzying Week Ends on Wall Street, Dangers Linger
snippet: As a week of volatile trading drew to a close, many think the Wall Street roller coaster ride is likely to continue — and there may be more drops ahead.
lead_paragraph: One of the most tumultuous weeks on Wall Street ended on Friday with the markets not that far from where they started, but with worries about the United States economy and the threat of a financial crisis in Europe undiminished.

main_headline: Why It Shouldn’t Have Been a Lost Decade for Investors
snippet: Too many people focus solely on the S.&P. 500 when measuring investors’ returns. So what would a truly diversified portfolio have earned?
lead_paragraph: When people talk about being a buy-and-hold investor these days, they are often confronted by others who declare that the last 10 years were a “lost decade.”

main_headline: Why It Shouldn’t Have Been a Lost Decade for Investors

lead_paragraph: When people talk about being a buy-and-hold investor these days, they are often confronted by others who declare that the last 10 years were a “lost decade.”

main_headline: Why (and How) Diversified Investors Win
snippet: A mix of stocks and bonds reduces volatility (and the anxiety that so many people feel today) without sacrificing much in the way of returns.
lead_paragraph: Diversification remains one of the most fundamental investing principles, and it’s often one of the most misunderstood. In order to understand diversification you first have to take a comprehensive view of the process of planning a portfolio.

main_headline: Market Swings Are Becoming New Standard
snippet: Recent stock fluctuations have caused experts to ask whether there are new forces at work in the market that make trading permanently more erratic.
lead_paragraph: The stock market just can’t seem to make up its mind.

main_headline: S.&P. 500 Declined 14% in 3rd Quarter
snippet: Major stock indexes declined in the third quarter on worries about the economy in the United States and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Stocks fell on Friday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to its biggest quarterly drop since 2008 — 14 percent. Reports from China and Germany fueled the decline on concerns that the global economy is slowing.

main_headline: Volatility, Thy Name Is E.T.F.
snippet: Some investors like Douglas A. Kass, the founder and president of Seabreeze Partners Management, attribute late-day market swings to leveraged exchange-traded funds.
lead_paragraph: Did you watch the markets on Monday? In the last 18 minutes of trading, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index jumped more than 10 points with no news to account for the rally. If you were left scratching your head, you were not alone.

main_headline: A World of Alternatives That Goes Beyond Stocks and Bonds
snippet: Funds that invest in commodities, real estate and currencies can provide a buffer against the volatility of stocks and bonds.
lead_paragraph: As the stock market continues to roil with no sign of abating, many investors have turned to alternative investments in hedging strategies.

main_headline: Volatile, but Nearly Running in Place
snippet: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has gained very little ground while moving up and down in great leaps. It may signal a sea change in the market.
lead_paragraph: RARELY has a stock market been so wild and moved so little.

main_headline: Off the Charts: Excess Stock Market Volatility
snippet: Excess stock market volatility ­ — price moves that get reversed in a few days or weeks — has risen to levels seen only three times before in the past 60 years: after the 1987 stock market crash, near the bottom of the market decline in 2002 and d...
lead_paragraph: Excess stock market volatility ­ — price moves that get reversed in a few days or weeks — has risen to levels seen only three times before in the past 60 years: after the 1987 stock market crash, near the bottom of the market decline in 2002 and during the financial crisis and recession of 2008 and 2009. The charts show the difference between the amount the Standard & Poor’s 500 moved over each 13-week period and the total of the daily changes, without regard to whether the daily move was up or down, and expresses the amount as a percentage of the index value at the beginning of each 13-week period. In a market that went up every day, or down every day, over a 13-week period, the figure would be zero. Highlighted areas show recessions.

main_headline: A Trusted Market Predictor Falters
snippet: The third year of a presidential term has been a boon year for investing in the Standard & Poor’s 500 — until now.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the most reliable guides to investing in the American stock market — to buy during the third year of a presidential term — is in danger of failing for the first time since the Great Depression.

main_headline: Off the Charts: The Charm of the Third Year
snippet: Since World War II, investors in American stocks have always made money during the third year of presidential terms. But with one month left, 2011 could be the first such year to see losses since 1939.
lead_paragraph: Since World War II, investors in American stocks have always made money during the third year of presidential terms. But with one month left, 2011 could be the first such year to see losses since 1939.

main_headline: Commodities Companies Help Lift Markets
snippet: Energy and raw material companies advanced, taking investors’ minds off the possible downgrade of European debt.
lead_paragraph: Stock indexes were mixed on Friday as gains among commodity producers helped overcome debt-crisis concerns prompted by Fitch Ratings’ warning that it might cut ratings of European nations.

main_headline: The Finds of the Lost Decade
snippet: While betting on a large-cap index may not have paid off in the last dozen years, other kinds of stock investments have fared well.
lead_paragraph: WITH only a week left in 2011, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has a dubious distinction: its performance has been far worse than that of a basic basket of bonds in the last 12 years. But while betting on a large-cap stock index may not have paid off over that time, it would be wrong to assume that this has been the case for all sectors of the market.

main_headline: A Razor-Thin Decline in Stocks
snippet: It was a down year for the American stock market, at least by one measure. But the margin was tiny.
lead_paragraph: It was a down year for the American stock market, at least by one measure. But the margin was tiny.

main_headline: Finding Optimism in a Longer View of Equities
snippet: Savers confident enough to believe better times will return within a few years should hope the gloom lasts a bit longer.

main_headline: Analyzing the Analysts’ Investment Predictions
snippet: Prognosticators who were interviewed each quarter of 2011 reviewed their successes and missteps.
lead_paragraph: I’M not the only one who has seen prognosticators through the years make a wrong call — Dow 36,000! Dow 5,000! But I can’t recall any of them being asked to explain months later why they slipped up.

main_headline: How Dividends Could Save the Day
snippet: Investors’ faith in the corporate profit picture is starting to wane, and for good reason. But dividend-paying stocks could offer some hope for market bulls.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the global economy slowed last year, investors looking for reasons to be bullish could at least point to one positive sign: the continued strength of corporate profits.

main_headline: Trading Year Starts Off With a Rally
snippet: A report on manufacturing in December fueled sharp gains on Wall Street on the year’s first day of trading, but volume was thin.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street stocks ushered in the first day of trading in the new year with a strong rally as investors were buoyed by a report that showed manufacturing strength in the American economy.

main_headline: Trading Year Starts Off With a Rally

lead_paragraph: Wall Street stocks ushered in the first day of trading in the new year with a strong rally as investors were buoyed by a report that showed manufacturing strength in the American economy.

main_headline: A Historical Cycle Bodes Ill for the Markets
snippet: In what appears to be a recurring 15-year cycle, the compound annual return of the S.& P. stock index peaks at more than 15 percent, then plunges. It’s plunge time.
lead_paragraph: AT the turn of the last century, it was widely accepted that American stocks were virtually certain to be good long-term investments. Now, far fewer people are confident of that.

main_headline: Off the Charts: Similar Cycles for Stocks
snippet: The total return, after inflation, of stocks over 15-year periods seems to be repeating the pattern it mapped out decades ago. The compound annual total real return of the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index peaked at more than 15 percent in 1999, a...
lead_paragraph: The total return, after inflation, of stocks over 15-year periods seems to be repeating the pattern it mapped out decades ago. The compound annual total real return of the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index peaked at more than 15 percent in 1999, and has since fallen to just 3 percent. That peak was similar to the earlier peak, reached in 1964. After that 1964 peak, the stock market lost momentum and then entered a bear market. By 1979, the market had failed to keep up with inflation over the previous 15 years.

main_headline: Dividends Rise in Sign of Recovery
snippet: If analysts’ forecasts come true, higher dividend payouts will continue in 2012, as companies release more cash and try to win over investors.
lead_paragraph: Every year since 1976, McDonald’s has increased its annual payout to shareholders. This year it will keep the streak alive, raising its annual dividend to $2.80. In doing so, it will join a broad range of companies that weathered a challenging economy and are now delivering their best payments to shareholders since the financial crisis.

main_headline: This Bull Market Is Hard to Pin Down

main_headline: Economic Reports for the Week of July 29

lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released will include pending home sales for June (Monday); the Standard & Poor’s Case-Shiller home price index for May and the consumer confidence index for July (Tuesday); the first estimate of second-quarter gross domestic product, ADP employment for July, and the Chicago Purchasing Manager Index report for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, Institute for Supply Management data for July and auto sales for July (Thursday); and the United States unemployment report for July, factory orders for June and consumer spending for June (Friday).

main_headline: For Markets, a Shutdown Is Usually a Ripple
snippet: Previous government shutdowns have not been catastrophic to the markets, but no precedent exists for how they might react to a failure to raise the debt ceiling.
lead_paragraph: As a government shutdown draws closer, many analysts are looking to past shutdowns for some guide as to what might happen — particularly in the markets. The precedent is not all that frightening, according to data put together by Joseph P. Quinlan, chief market strategist at U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management. The chart below shows how much the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index moved from the beginning of the shutdown to the end. The last time it happened, in early 1996, the market actually ended up slightly.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande suffered another setback on Friday, as Standard & Poor’s cut France’s credit rating, saying it did not believe the government’s current policy course would restore growth.

main_headline: New Market Benchmarks Show a Lack of Options
snippet: A consensus of professional strategists became convinced months ago that compared with bonds, stocks were a good bet.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rallied past two psychological barriers Monday morning, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average over 16,000 and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index beyond 1,800 for the first time, as investors still saw opportunities in the market.

main_headline: A Record Market Is Not All That It Seems
snippet: It is hard to compare today’s stock market with the one in 2000, as measured by the S.&.P 500, and not just because of inflation.
lead_paragraph: THE stock market flirted with historical highs this week, with the Dow Jones industrial average trading over 16,000 and the Standard & Poor’s 500 exceeding 1,800 for a time.

main_headline: Off the Charts: Stars of 2000 Burned Out
snippet: The Standard & Poor’s index of 500 stocks traded above 1,800 this week for the first time ever. But after adjusting for inflation, the index still remains well below where it was in 2000.
lead_paragraph: The Standard & Poor’s index of 500 stocks traded above 1,800 this week for the first time ever. But after adjusting for inflation, the index still remains well below where it was in 2000.

main_headline: Factories Worldwide Are Showing Momentum
snippet: Figures showed factories in the United States operating at the most robust pace since the spring of 2011, and well above the level economists had expected for November.
lead_paragraph: Bucking fears of a sharp brake on growth after the government shutdown in the United States and earlier signs of distress in Europe and Asia, global manufacturing activity sped up in November, raising hopes for a broader global economic turnaround in the coming year.

snippet: Recent auction reports may give the impression that the art market is skyrocketing. But, to judge by the Mei Moses index, which compares repeat sales of the same artworks, the market has has remained relatively flat over the last two years.

main_headline: For Stocks, an Amazingly Good Year
snippet: Despite turbulence in Washington, China and Europe, which threatened to pull the world into another recession, stock prices just kept rising in 2013.
lead_paragraph: It was the market rally that defied gravity and left many with a case of vertigo.

main_headline: Divining a 5-Year Investment Strategy
snippet: Experts weigh in on where the economy is heading and what kind of strategies investors may want to explore.
lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago, it would have been easy to predict that the stock market would be higher today than it was then. But no one would have paid attention. Stocks were in a free fall and wouldn’t hit bottom for two more months.

main_headline: Two Who Got 2013 Right See 2014 as Much the Same
snippet: Widespread optimism about the stock market, the economy, and corporate profits, but pessimism when it comes to the bond market.
lead_paragraph: After a banner year for stocks and a rocky one for bonds, market forecasters are remarkably consistent in their forecasts for 2014: more of the same.

main_headline: For Carlyle, Private Equity Business Is a Standout
snippet: The big investment firm said on Wednesday that its private equity funds rose in value by 9 percent in the fourth quarter of 2013, bringing the year’s gains to 30 percent.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group manages a range of different investments, including private equity, hedge funds and real estate. But its bread-and-butter business of private equity was a standout last year.

main_headline: A Market Streak Has Ended, but the Echoes Haven’t
snippet: A two-year pattern turned a bargain-basement stock market into a much more expensive one.
lead_paragraph: After two improbable, gravity-defying years, the streak is over.

snippet: The video subscription service was the S.&P. 500’s biggest winner last year, but some analysts worry about the stock’s dizzying climb.
lead_paragraph: I confess: I’m one of those people who binged on “House of Cards” last February when Netflix released all 13 episodes in one fell swoop.

main_headline: An About-Face for the Stock Market’s 5-Year Return
snippet: A huge change in a popular market gauge suggests that investors’ long-term view should be much longer.
lead_paragraph: Take the long view. That’s standard advice in investing, and it makes sense. After all, if you’ve salted money away for a serious purpose like retiring or buying a house or paying for a child’s education, you really don’t want to focus on how the stock market has done today or on what it might do tomorrow. You need a longer perspective.

main_headline: Taking Their Investments Elsewhere
snippet: For the first time since 1992, foreigners were net sellers of American stocks in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury on Tuesday released its estimates of international capital flows into and out of the United States, and they indicate that foreigners were net sellers of $40.2 billion of American stocks in 2013. That is hardly a large amount, but it is the first year since 1992 that they were net sellers.

main_headline: Emerging, but No Longer a Mother Lode of Profits
snippet: Multinational corporations that crowed for years about their presence in booming emerging markets are now blaming turmoil in those regions for dents in their bottom lines.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to investing in emerging markets, few companies have been as gung-ho as Diageo, the British maker of the Guinness, Johnnie Walker and Smirnoff brands. But now that troubles are cropping up in many such countries around the world, Diageo has turned from cheerleader to excuse-monger.

lead_paragraph: The price of Google shares is going to be cut in half on Thursday.

main_headline: The Oracle of Omaha, Lately Looking a Bit Ordinary
snippet: Yes, Warren Buffett’s 49-year market record is stellar. Just don’t count the last five.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett is probably the most famous investor of his generation, and for good reason: His track record over the long term is a thing of beauty.

snippet: A turnaround for highflying tech and biotech stocks like Tesla, NXP Semiconductor and Alexion signals a potential shift that the time to chase eye-popping growth may be over.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past year, Tesla Motors seemingly could do no wrong in investors’ eyes.

main_headline: A Chance for a Market’s Wallflowers to Bloom
snippet: The sell-off is providing a rare moment in the sun for so-called value investors, who focus on out-of-favor stocks with relatively low valuations.
lead_paragraph: In January, Seth Klarman, a billionaire who runs the Boston-based Baupost Group investment partnership, warned in his annual letter to clients that “a skeptic would have to be blind not to see bubbles inflating” and cited the “nosebleed stock market valuations” of companies like Netflix and Tesla Motors.

main_headline: Fast-Growing Sectors Drive a Market Sell-Off
snippet: Despite strong data on new claims for unemployment, investors were taking defensive positions and selling so-called momentum stocks.
lead_paragraph: Investors dumped Internet, biotechnology and other fast-growing companies at a dizzying pace on Thursday, dragging down the rest of the stock market and stirring up painful memories of the dot-com bust in 2000.

main_headline: U.S. Markets Quiet After Global Sell-Off
snippet: Stocks on Wall Street were down slightly after the previous session’s steep losses spread to Asia and Europe.
lead_paragraph: European stocks joined a global slide on Friday after a big drop in Tokyo that followed a sharp sell-off in Internet and biotechnology shares in the United States a day earlier.

main_headline: The Re-education of a Brash Young Stock Picker
snippet: Despite all his success picking stocks, Randy Kurtz now mostly buys index and exchange-traded funds for his clients.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, Randy Kurtz made an extraordinary bet on himself, the stock market and his ability to pick a few winners.

main_headline: Maybe There’s Life in the Old Bull Market Yet
snippet: To Laszlo Birinyi, the veteran strategist, the stock market’s recent sobriety may well be a sign of good things to come.
lead_paragraph: Worried about the stock market? There’s no shortage of reasons to fret.

main_headline: Fear of Equities Drives More Investors to Cash
snippet: Millennials are hoarding cash at the same rate as baby boomers, researchers found, suggesting that anxiety about market crashes has yet to subside.
lead_paragraph: IF a lot of your portfolio is still sitting in cash after a five-year bull market in equities, you’re not alone. Investors at all wealth levels around the world are holding substantial amounts of cash that have increased since 2012. What this means for investors and the markets that depend on their money is intriguing.

main_headline: Markets Are Less Volatile. Should We Worry?
snippet: Wild swings in the market have become uncommon, signalling there is less fear among investors. That should be good. Unless it’s not.
lead_paragraph: If the stock market was a person, right now it would be a supremely easygoing retiree on the beach in Key West drinking a piña colada. Mr. Market is very, very relaxed.

main_headline: Mimicking the S.&P. With an Index for Ad Prices at 500 Publishers
snippet: The RTB 500 is meant to provide the real-time price of media on 500 leading publishers’ sites.
lead_paragraph: A LEADING advertising trade publisher, MediaPost Communications, is seeking to be a kind of Dow Jones or Standard & Poor’s for Madison Avenue, introducing an index that intends to track in real time the movements in price for ads bought and sold on the websites of 500 publishers.

main_headline: Dow Closes Above 17,000 as Stock Rally Outpaces Economy
snippet: The current bull market has lasted nearly 64 months, making it the fourth-longest since the crash of 1929, and investors are showing few signs of slowing down.
lead_paragraph: The stock market, continuing a remarkable ascent that began in the darkness of the last recession, surged past a milestone on Thursday after a strong jobs report indicated that the economy might finally be gaining steam.

main_headline: Today’s Titans Can Learn From Fall of U.S. Steel
snippet: A once-powerful corporation has been dropped from the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, but the fact that it’s down may not mean that it’s out.
lead_paragraph: It has been 55 years since bitter labor relations exploded into one of the longest and most debilitating strikes the United States has ever seen.

main_headline: In Investing, 'When' Matters Just as Much as 'What'
snippet: More examples, this time from real life, of how the timing of stock market peaks and troughs can drastically affect retirement savings.
lead_paragraph: Today I brought you the story of four hypothetical savers to show how timing can be unlucky for some investors who are saving for retirement via the stock market. If you’re building retirement savings little by little over decades, it matters a great deal not just what the stock market or other investments return, but when those returns materialize.

lead_paragraph: The news media typically covers stock markets using one exceedingly simple frame: Market goes up, good! Market goes down, bad!

snippet: Plaintiffs filed 78 new federal class-action securities cases in the first half of 2014, about 18 percent fewer than historic averages for the last 16 years.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders may be feeling a little less litigious lately.

snippet: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index briefly topped 2,000 before closing a bit shy of the mark following a meeting of central bankers in Jackson Hole, Wyo., last weekend.
lead_paragraph: Updated | The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index rose above 2,000 for the first time on Monday after a meeting of central bankers opened the door to more stimulus measures.

main_headline: Demand Up, U.S. Economy Shows Gains
snippet: New data suggests an increased demand by businesses for manufactured goods in July, as well as rising consumer confidence.
lead_paragraph: The American economy is gaining renewed momentum, with data released on Tuesday suggesting strong demand by businesses for airplanes, machinery and other manufactured items, as well as rising confidence among consumers, despite a cooling in the housing market.

main_headline: For First Time, S.&P. 500 Closes Above 2,000
snippet: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index reached the milestone tentatively, on lazy trading and only barely above the 2,000 mark.
lead_paragraph: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index reached a milestone on Tuesday, closing above 2,000 for the first time ever, if just barely. It was a lazy day of trading that picked up on some encouraging signs in the United States economy, but not enough for sustained optimism in the market.

snippet: A growing number of big American multinational companies have begun to suffer from lower oil prices and a strong dollar.
lead_paragraph: What is good for the American consumer may be less so for big American companies.

main_headline: Do Activist Investors Target Female C.E.O.s?
snippet: Only 23 women lead companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index. Yet at least a quarter of them have fallen into the cross hairs of activist investors.
lead_paragraph: Indra K. Nooyi. Marissa Mayer. Ellen J. Kullman. Irene B. Rosenfeld. Meg Whitman. Mary T. Barra.

main_headline: As Hedge Fund Returns Falter, Money Continues to Flow In
snippet: Despite their performance record, the promise of higher returns with lower risk — or even zero risk — beckons.
lead_paragraph: Another year, and another mediocre performance by hedge funds, to put it kindly. The Barclay Hedge Fund Index gained a meager 2.89 percent in 2014, while the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index gained over 13 percent and the Barclays United States Aggregate Bond Index rose over 5 percent.

main_headline: Warren Buffett’s Awesome Feat at Berkshire Hathaway, Revisited
snippet: In its 50 years under Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway’s shares have gained a cumulative 1,826,163 percent.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett is taking a victory lap, and on the 50th anniversary of his reign at Berkshire Hathaway he is entitled to it. From a failing New England textile company, Berkshire became the vehicle for one of capitalism’s greatest investing feats.

main_headline: Apple’s Entry Will Help an Antiquated Dow Catch Up
snippet: The Dow dates from a computer-free era when working out the average of 30 stock prices counted as added value. Including Apple in the index was overdue.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s entry into the Dow Jones industrial average is a bit like polishing an antique. The average share price of 30 stocks selected by committee will finally include the world’s biggest company in place of AT&T. It’s an overdue move for an outdated yardstick — one that, like landlines and checkbooks, lives on.

main_headline: Consumers Thrive as Oil Shares Dive
snippet: Energy stocks dropped while consumer discretionary shares rose on the assumption that people will put more cash into nonessential products and services.
lead_paragraph: A 50 percent drop in the price of crude oil in a matter of months is a highly unusual occurrence. But that’s what happened from the beginning of July 2014 to the end of this March. The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index rose 5 percent in that period, but individual parts of the market reacted in very different ways.

main_headline: Health Care Has Been This Quarter’s Elixir for Stock Funds

snippet: While the pandemic has made it hard to offer forecasts, some corporate leaders said things might be getting a little better — or at least no worse.
lead_paragraph: Companies releasing first-quarter results in recent weeks have detailed how the coronavirus pandemic is crushing their business, and many have gone so far as to stop offering forecasts for the rest of the year, claiming the future is just too uncertain.

main_headline: Dismal Earnings, Bullish Stock Investors and the Fed’s Invisible Hand
snippet: First-quarter profits shrank at the fastest rate in over a decade. Analysts don’t like what they see coming down the pike. Investors keep pushing stocks higher.

main_headline: Why the Stock Market Just Doesn’t Care
